awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Adaptable Invention Disclosure System
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project continues previous development of an invention disclosure tool that allows users to draft a United States Patent and Trademark Office compliant patent applications by using an intuitive interface and game-based educational tools to draft patent applications. Inventors and small companies having no background in patent law and patent-application drafting strategies struggle with properly describing their inventions.  Overcoming this lack of understanding on the part of the inventor requires a great deal of one-on-one educational training with a patent professional in order to draft a quality patent application. However, engaging a patent professional is costly and time consuming. This project expands the capacity of the invention disclosure software by allowing users to configure and customize the software for specific types of inventions and arts.

Specifically, this project proposes a new customization tool for integration with the existing invention disclosure tool to allow for widespread adoption into varied technology arts. The customization tool comprises software modules that allow end users to identify and create narrative goals, design software interfaces by configuring display rules, design text output state configurations based on logical operators, design natural language output, design the natural language generated output that is desired for that product type and configure template text, token input, and grammar associations, and determine the position of natural language output into an overall document structure. This customization tool will allow for rapid, scalable distribution of the product to be driven by end users rather than through a traditional software development process, e.g., 1) researching, 2) market testing, and 3) designing and implementing each new version of a product for different technology arts.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

Patents are integral parts of the US economy. A recent study by the USPTO suggested that utility patent-intensive industries are responsible for $4.4 trillion worth of economic benefit in the U.S. 

For would-be U.S. inventors any methods or technology for them that would:

  • Increase patent accessibility

  • Decrease the cost of patent preparation

  • Increase patent value

  • Increase patent transparency

may be beneficial. 

 

 For helping increase patent accessibility:

  • A new strategy for teaching patent law without using legal terms was created.

  • Education word count per legal statutory patent rejection was greatly reduced (> 99%)

 

For helping increase patent quality:

  • A high (transparent) value patent quality metric was created.

  • For helping decrease the cost of patent preparation

  • A lower cost patent preparation model was created wherein:

    • Inventor and practitioner mutually agree upon patent quality metrics beforehand.

    • Practitioner switches role from a) application drafter ->  b) quality verifier

  • Provisional-patent software was created for inventors to work with practitioners wherein:

    • Inventor creates a minimum invention summary  

    • Inventor captures rough market and patentability  

    • Inventor captures target customer, unit price, total addressable market 

    • Inventor evaluates 35 USC 101 patentability 

    • Inventor captures possession before filing  

      • Inventor captures own functional requirements 

      • Inventor creates their own glossary or invention terms  

      • Inventor describes functional requirements using their invention glossary 

      • Inventor captures and arranges the required steps.  

    • Inventor completes rough drawings 

      • Inventor creates rough drawings for all requirement types 

      • The inventor labels all requirements on each rough drawing page 

      • The inventor lassos the design on the drawing for each requirement  

      • The inventor completes patent drawings  

    • Inventor captures 35 USC 112 A  enablement before filing  

      • Inventor captures performance requirements  

    • Inventor compares for priort art

    • Inventor files a provisional application  

      • Inventor completes fill-in-blank patent specification 

    • Practitioner drafts provisional claims set  

    • Practitioner files provisional patent application

 

For helping increase patent value:

  • An observation was made that patent legal criteria likely have societal-value dependencies 

  • Possession was identified as the most important criteria for transparent patent value.

  • A patent value model based on information dependency was created

  • A high (transparent) value patent data model was created.  

 

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2024
Modified by: Eric Leininger

Project Outcomes


Patents are integral parts of the US economy. A recent study by the USPTO suggested that utility patent-intensive industries are responsible for $4.4 trillion worth of economic benefit in the U.S.


For would-be U.S. inventors any methods or technology for them that would:




Increase patent accessibility




Decrease the cost of patent preparation




Increase patent value




Increase patent transparency




may be beneficial.





For helping increase patent accessibility:

A new strategy for teaching patent law without using legal terms was created.



Education word count per legal statutory patent rejection was greatly reduced ( 99%)







For helping increase patent quality:




A high (transparent) value patent quality metric was created.






For helping decrease the cost of patent preparation






A lower cost patent preparation model was created wherein:




Inventor and practitioner mutually agree upon patent quality metrics beforehand.




Practitioner switches role froma) application drafter - b) quality verifier






Provisional-patent software was created for inventors to work with practitioners wherein:




Inventor creates a minimum invention summary




Inventor captures rough market and patentability




Inventor captures target customer, unit price, total addressable market




Inventor evaluates 35 USC 101 patentability




Inventor captures possession before filing

Inventor describes functional requirements using their invention glossary




Inventor captures and arranges the required steps.






Inventor completes rough drawings




Inventor creates rough drawings for all requirement types




The inventor labels all requirements on each rough drawing page




The inventor lassos the design on the drawing for each requirement




The inventor completes patent drawings






Inventor captures 35 USC 112 A enablement before filing

Inventor compares for priort art

Practitioner drafts provisional claims set




Practitioner files provisional patent application









For helping increase patent value:




An observation was made that patent legal criteria likely have societal-value dependencies




Possession was identified as the most important criteria for transparent patent value.

A high (transparent) value patent data model was created.
